subdomain: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

questions.stem: A researcher studies whether the relationship between test anxiety and performance differs for students with high versus low self-efficacy. In this study, self-efficacy is best described as a:
questions.explanation: A moderator variable affects the strength or direction of the relationship between IV and DV. Here, self-efficacy moderates the anxiety-performance relationship (the effect may differ for high vs. low self-efficacy students). This creates an interaction effect in statistical terms.

questions.stem: A researcher proposes that therapy reduces depression, which then leads to improved quality of life. Depression in this model is best described as a:
questions.explanation: A mediator variable explains the mechanism through which IV affects DV—it lies in the causal pathway. Therapy → Depression reduction → Quality of life improvement. Depression mediates (transmits) the effect of therapy on quality of life. This addresses 'how' the effect works.

questions.stem: Temperature in Celsius (where 0 represents an arbitrary point, not absence of heat) is measured on which scale?
questions.explanation: Interval scales have equal intervals between values but no true zero point. Celsius 0° is arbitrary (water freezing), not absolute absence of heat. You cannot say 20°C is 'twice as hot' as 10°C. Temperature in Kelvin (with absolute zero) would be ratio scale.

questions.stem: A researcher operationalizes 'intelligence' as the total score on the WAIS-IV. This operational definition represents which type of variable?
questions.explanation: Intelligence is a latent construct (not directly observable). The WAIS-IV score is the observed/manifest variable—the concrete, measurable operationalization. Construct validity concerns whether the observed measure adequately represents the latent construct.

questions.stem: In a study of therapy effectiveness, participants' age, gender, and baseline severity are measured but not manipulated. These variables should be classified as:
questions.explanation: Subject/participant/attribute variables are pre-existing characteristics of participants that cannot be randomly assigned or manipulated. They can be used as covariates, blocking variables, or quasi-independent variables but don't allow causal conclusions like true IVs.

questions.stem: Which variables are measured on an ORDINAL scale? Select all that apply.

options.text: Ranking of job applicants from best to worst
Likert scale ratings (strongly disagree to strongly agree)

questions.explanation: Ordinal scales have meaningful order but unequal/unknown intervals. Rankings, SES categories, and Likert scales are ordinal (though Likert is often treated as interval). Temperature has equal intervals (interval scale). Reaction time has equal intervals and true zero (ratio scale).

questions.stem: Which statements about RATIO scales are TRUE? Select all that apply.

options.text: They have a true zero point indicating complete absence
Ratios between values are meaningful (e.g., twice as much)
Intervals between adjacent values are equal
Most psychological variables are measured at this level
Examples include weight, height, and reaction time

questions.explanation: Ratio scales have all interval properties plus true zero, allowing ratio comparisons. Physical measurements (weight, height, time) are ratio. Most psychological variables (IQ, personality scores) are interval at best—there's no 'zero intelligence' or 'zero extraversion.'

questions.stem: Which are examples of CONFOUNDING variables? Select all that apply.

options.text: Age differs between treatment and control groups
Treatment group also receives more therapist attention
The dependent variable is measured unreliably
Participants in one condition are tested at different time of day
The independent variable has three levels

questions.explanation: Confounds are variables that vary systematically with the IV, providing alternative explanations. Age differences, differential attention, and time-of-day differences all confound. Unreliable measurement adds error (not confounding). Number of IV levels is design choice, not confound.

questions.stem: Which statements correctly distinguish between moderators and mediators? Select all that apply.

options.text: Moderators indicate for whom or when an effect occurs
Mediators explain why or how an effect occurs
Moderators are statistically tested as interaction effects
Mediators must be affected by the independent variable
Moderators and mediators are interchangeable terms

questions.explanation: Moderators and mediators are distinct. Moderators: for whom/when (interaction, boundary conditions). Mediators: why/how (mechanism, causal pathway). Mediators must be affected by IV and affect DV. Test moderators via interaction terms; test mediators via path analysis or Sobel test.

questions.stem: A researcher wants to control for the effects of baseline depression when analyzing treatment outcomes. Which approaches are appropriate? Select all that apply.

options.text: Include baseline depression as a covariate (ANCOVA)
Match participants on baseline depression before random assignment
Ignore baseline depression since randomization controls for it

questions.explanation: Multiple valid approaches: ANCOVA (statistically control), matching (equate groups), stratified randomization (ensure balance), change scores (remove baseline). Randomization doesn't guarantee groups are equal on specific variables—especially with small samples, additional control is wise.

questions.stem: Match each variable type with its correct definition.

columns.text: Variable that varies with IV, threatens internal validity
Variable that may affect DV but is not of interest

questions.explanation: IV: manipulated/presumed cause. DV: measured outcome. Confound: varies with IV, provides alternative explanation (threatens validity). Extraneous: other variables affecting DV that should be controlled but aren't the focus (become confounds if uncontrolled).

questions.stem: Match each measurement scale with the appropriate statistical operations.

columns.text: Mean, SD, Pearson r (but no ratio statements)
All operations including ratios (e.g., twice as much)

questions.explanation: Scale determines permissible operations. Nominal: frequency counts, mode. Ordinal: median, percentiles, Spearman. Interval: mean, SD, parametric tests (but can't say 'twice as much'). Ratio: all operations including meaningful ratios. Using inappropriate statistics yields meaningless results.

questions.stem: For each research scenario, select ALL variable types that apply to 'gender' in the study.

rows.text: Comparing therapy outcomes between men and women
Testing if gender moderates treatment effectiveness
Controlling for gender statistically when comparing treatments
Randomly assigning gender to participants (impossible scenario)

questions.explanation: Gender cannot be randomly assigned, so it's always a quasi-IV/subject variable in real research. When testing if effects differ by gender, it's also a moderator. When controlled statistically, it's a covariate. Only if it could be randomly assigned (impossible) would it be a true IV.

questions.stem: Select ALL correct statements about each measurement scale.
questions.explanation: Nominal: categories without order. Ordinal: ordered but unequal intervals. Interval: equal intervals, meaningful mean, no true zero. Ratio: all interval properties plus true zero (allowing ratios). Mean is technically only appropriate for interval+ scales.

questions.stem: In an experiment, the {{blank1}} is the variable manipulated by the researcher, and the {{blank2}} is the measured outcome. Variables that could provide alternative explanations for results are called {{blank3}} variables, while variables that are measured but not of primary interest are called {{blank4}} variables.
questions.explanation: IV = manipulated presumed cause. DV = measured presumed effect. Confounds = systematic sources of alternative explanations. Extraneous/control = other variables affecting DV that aren't the research focus but need to be managed.

questions.stem: Stevens proposed four levels of measurement. {{blank1}} is the lowest level where numbers serve only as labels. {{blank2}} adds rank order but intervals aren't equal. {{blank3}} has equal intervals but no true zero. {{blank4}} has all properties including true zero, allowing ratio statements.
questions.explanation: Stevens' hierarchy: Nominal (categories), Ordinal (ranked), Interval (equal intervals), Ratio (true zero). Each level adds properties. Most psychological measures are interval at best; physical measurements (weight, time) are ratio.

questions.stem: A researcher finds that cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) reduces anxiety more than supportive therapy for patients with high motivation, but both therapies work equally well for patients with low motivation.

options.text: Test the interaction between therapy type and motivation
Conduct separate analyses for high and low motivation groups
Treat motivation as the dependent variable
Motivation is a MODERATOR of treatment effect
Motivation is a MEDIATOR of treatment effect
CBT is more effective for highly motivated patients
Treatment should be matched to patient motivation level
CBT is ineffective for low motivation patients

questions.explanation: This is moderation: the treatment effect differs depending on motivation level (interaction). Motivation moderates (qualifies) the relationship between treatment and outcome. Clinical implication: match treatment to patient characteristics. CBT still works for low motivation—just not better than supportive therapy.

questions.stem: A researcher theorizes that mindfulness training reduces stress, and this stress reduction leads to improved immune function. The full pathway is: Mindfulness → Stress reduction → Immune improvement.

options.text: Measure stress at multiple time points
Test whether mindfulness affects stress (path a)
Test whether stress affects immune function controlling for mindfulness (path b)
Only measure immune function at the end
Immune function is an independent variable
Show mindfulness reduces stress (a path significant)
Show stress reduction improves immune function (b path significant)
Show direct mindfulness→immune effect decreases when stress is controlled
Full mediation requires direct effect to become zero

questions.explanation: This is mediation (causal chain). Stress reduction is the mediator explaining WHY mindfulness affects immunity. Testing requires: (a) IV→mediator, (b) mediator→DV controlling for IV, and (c) indirect effect significance. Full mediation: direct effect becomes non-significant when mediator is included.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL examples of variables measured at the INTERVAL or RATIO level.
questions.passage: Psychological research uses variables measured at different levels. [IQ scores with a mean of 100 and SD of 15] are commonly used. [Diagnostic categories (depression, anxiety, no diagnosis)] sort participants into groups. [Reaction time measured in milliseconds] is often used in cognitive research. [Therapy satisfaction ratings on a 1-5 scale] capture patient opinions. [Weight measured in kilograms] is sometimes relevant in eating disorder research. [Birth order (first, middle, last)] may influence personality.

highlightableSegments.text: IQ scores with a mean of 100 and SD of 15
Therapy satisfaction ratings on a 1-5 scale

questions.explanation: Interval/ratio: IQ (interval—no true zero intelligence), reaction time (ratio—true zero possible), weight (ratio—true zero). Nominal: diagnostic categories, birth order. Likert scales are technically ordinal (though often treated as interval controversially).

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that correctly describe CONFOUNDING variables.
questions.passage: Confounding variables are important to understand in research design. [A confound is an extraneous variable that varies systematically with the independent variable]. [Random assignment eliminates all possible confounds]. [In observational studies, confounds make causal conclusions problematic]. [A confound must affect the dependent variable to be a threat to validity]. [Confounds can be controlled through matching, statistical control, or random assignment]. [Any variable that differs between groups is automatically a confound].

highlightableSegments.text: A confound is an extraneous variable that varies systematically with the independent variable
Random assignment eliminates all possible confounds
In observational studies, confounds make causal conclusions problematic
A confound must affect the dependent variable to be a threat to validity
Confounds can be controlled through matching, statistical control, or random assignment
Any variable that differs between groups is automatically a confound

questions.explanation: Correct: confounds covary with IV, make causal inference problematic, must affect DV, can be controlled multiple ways. Incorrect: random assignment distributes confounds but doesn't eliminate them (especially with small n); only variables that BOTH differ between groups AND affect DV are confounds.

questions.stem: Arrange Stevens' levels of measurement from LEAST to MOST informative.

items.text: Nominal: Categories without order (e.g., diagnosis type)
Ordinal: Ranked categories (e.g., mild, moderate, severe)
Interval: Equal intervals, arbitrary zero (e.g., IQ, temperature °C)
Ratio: Equal intervals, true zero (e.g., reaction time, weight)

questions.explanation: NOIR hierarchy: Nominal (categories) → Ordinal (rank order) → Interval (equal distances) → Ratio (true zero). Each level retains properties of lower levels and adds new ones. Higher levels permit more sophisticated statistical operations.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps for testing mediation according to Baron and Kenny's approach.

items.text: Step 1: Show that IV significantly affects DV (path c)
Step 2: Show that IV significantly affects the mediator (path a)
Step 3: Show that mediator affects DV when controlling for IV (path b)
Step 4: Show that IV→DV relationship (c') is reduced when mediator is included

questions.explanation: Baron & Kenny's classic mediation steps: (1) IV→DV (total effect), (2) IV→Mediator, (3) Mediator→DV controlling for IV, (4) reduction in direct effect when mediator included. Full mediation: c' becomes non-significant. Partial mediation: c' is reduced but still significant.

questions.stem: A researcher examines whether coping style moderates the relationship between stress and depression across stress levels.
questions.question: What pattern in this data indicates that coping style is a MODERATOR?

options.text: Both coping styles show increased depression with stress
The effect of stress on depression differs by coping style (interaction)
The lines are parallel, indicating no moderation

questions.explanation: Moderation is indicated by non-parallel lines (interaction). The stress-depression relationship is stronger for emotion-focused copers (steeper slope: 12→35) than problem-focused copers (10→18). This means coping style moderates how much stress affects depression.

questions.stem: A researcher tests mediation: Therapy → Self-Efficacy → Symptom Reduction. The data show path coefficients across the study.
questions.question: What do these coefficients suggest about mediation?

options.text: No mediation—all paths must be equal
Partial mediation—direct effect is reduced but not eliminated

questions.explanation: Path a (0.45) and b (0.52) are significant, indicating mediation pathway works. Total effect c (0.38) is reduced to c' (0.15) when mediator is included. Since c' isn't zero, this is PARTIAL mediation—self-efficacy explains some but not all of therapy's effect on symptoms.

questions.stem: Categorize each variable by its measurement scale.

items.text: DSM diagnosis (depression, anxiety, PTSD)
Symptom severity (none, mild, moderate, severe)
IQ score
Number of therapy sessions attended
Gender (male, female, non-binary)
Class rank (1st, 2nd, 3rd...)
Temperature in Celsius
Reaction time in milliseconds

questions.explanation: Nominal: categories without order (diagnosis, gender). Ordinal: ranked categories (severity, class rank). Interval: equal intervals, no true zero (IQ, Celsius). Ratio: equal intervals plus true zero (session count, reaction time).

questions.stem: Categorize each variable by its role in research.

items.text: Treatment condition (CBT vs. control)—manipulated by researcher
Depression score at end of treatment—measured outcome
Patient age—affects whether treatment works differently
Change in negative thoughts—explains why CBT reduces depression
Medication dosage—manipulated by researcher
Treatment severity—affects treatment response direction
Anxiety level at study end
Behavior activation—mechanism through which therapy works

questions.explanation: IV: manipulated cause. DV: measured outcome. Moderator: affects relationship strength/direction (for whom/when). Mediator: mechanism explaining why/how effect occurs (causal pathway).
